apps

Class RemotePath

  • java.lang.Object
    • apps.RemotePath

  • class RemotePath
extends Object
    Remote path parser.

    This path parser is used by all filesystem utility programs. It accepts paths in the remote path format. In this format, a full absolute path is given as hostname:path, where hostname is the hostname of a distributed filesystem naming server, and path is an absolute path to a file or directory on that naming server.

    This permits the user to, say, retrieve a file from the distributed filesystem by issuing a command such as 

        java -jar dfs.jar get unix.andrew.cmu.edu:/home/notes.txt ./
    assuming the filesystem code is packaged in an archive dfs.jar and there is a naming server running at unix.andrew.cmu.edu.

    There are several ways to abbreviate remote paths. This class is aware of two environment variables, DFSHOST and DFSCWD. By setting DFSHOST, it is possible to omit the host entirely. Then, a remote path such as 192.168.3.3:/path can be written simply as :/path or /path.

    The remote path given may be either absolute or relative. If the path is relative, then it is relative to an absolute path in the DFSCWD environment variable. Both absolute and relative paths may include the special components . and .., which refer to the current and parent directories, respectively. As an example, a path such as 192.168.3.3:/path/.. actually refers to the root directory of the filesystem hosted at 192.168.3.3. A path such as 192.168.3.3:index.html refers to index.html in the current directory. If the value of DFSCWD is /project2-master/javadoc, then the path is referring to /project2-master/javadoc/index.html on 192.168.3.3.

    The shortest remote path possible is :, which refers to the current directory on the current host. This path can be written in two ways: . is the other way.

    The environment variables DFSHOST and DFSCWD are meant to be set by an external script in response to a cd-like command. With a well-written script, they allow relatively easy navigation of the distributed filesystem from a shell, without a need to constantly type the same hostname and long absolute paths.

    • Constructor Detail

      • RemotePath

        RemotePath(String remote_path)
        Parses a remote path string and creates a RemotePath object.

        If the path string contains a colon character (:), everything preceding the colon is taken to be the hostname, and everything following the colon is taken to be the distributed filesystem path. If there is no colon, then the hostname is taken to be empty, and the path is taken to be the entire string.

        Parameters:
        remote_path - The raw path string to be parsed.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the path string is malformed.

      • RemotePath

        private RemotePath(RemotePath existing_path,
                   Path new_path)
        Creates a remote path object from the hostname of an existing object, and a replacement filesystem path.

        This constructor is used primarily for pretty-printing paths, to create a RemotePath object for access to its toString method.

        Parameters:
        existing_path - Existing RemotePath object.
        new_path - Replacement path portion for the new RemotePath. The hostname of existing_path is used for the new RemotePath.

    • Method Detail

      • parseHostname

        private String parseHostname(String hostname)
        Parses the hostname portion of a remote path.

        If the hostname given with the path is empty, the value of the DFSHOST environment variable is used for the hostname. If this environment variable is empty or undefined, then no hostname has been given, and the path, as given, cannot be parsed.

        Parameters:
        hostname - The hostname portion of the remote path given by the user. This is simply everything preceding the colon, if there is one, or the empty string if there is no colon.
        Returns:
        If the user gave a hostname, the hostname is returned. Otherwise, this method returns the value of the DFSHOST environment variable, if it is set.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the user has not specified a host in the remote path, and the DFSHOST environment variable is empty, undefined, or cannot be accessed.

      • parseRemotePath

        private Path parseRemotePath(String raw_path)
        Parses the path portion of a remote path.

        If the path portion begins with a forward slash (/), it is considered to be an absolute path. Otherwise, it is considered to be a path relative to the absolute path stored in the DFSCWD environment variable. In the first case, this method assembles a path starting from the root directory. In the second case, the path is assembled starting from the directory set by the environment variable. The special path components . and .. are interpreted as the current and parent directories, respectively, and may occur in both absolute and relative paths. Empty components are treated as references to the current directory.

        If the DFSCWD environment variable is not set, the default value of / is used instead.

        Parameters:
        raw_path - The path portion of the remote path given by the user. This is everything following the colon, if there is one, or the whole path string, if there is no colon.
        Returns:
        A Path object representing the filesystem path obtained from parsing the remote path given by the user according to the rules described above.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the user gave a relative path but DFSCWD is set and does not contain an absolute path, or cannot be accessed, if any path component contains an illegal character such as the colon (:), or if the user has made a reference to the parent of the root directory, for example by providing a path such as /...

      • parent

        RemotePath parent()
        Returns a RemotePath representing the parent directory of the given RemotePath.

        This is primarily used for pretty-printing parent paths. A new RemotePath object is created for access to its toString method.

        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the given remote path has no parent.

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Converts the path to a string for printing in error messages.

        The path is converted to the format hostname:path.

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
